Hi Drew, I believe that combining the 24 total scores into one score is c=
orrect.  It is true that standard NEAT implementations usually require at s=
ome point a single score for each individual, so they have to be aggregated=
 eventually.  I don't think there is anything wrong with your interpretatio=
n.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "ze_dakster" <drew.kirkpatrick@...> w=
rote:
>
> Ken,
> 
> I'm in the process of coding up a "remake" of the robot=
 duel experiment from your paper on evolutionary complexification, and I ha=
d a question regarding having multiple fitness scores per host. 
> 
> So yo=
u have 12 opponents per host genome, played twice (east/west start). I see =
you're combining the east/west scores into a single fitness score per oppon=
ent, but it sounds like from the paper you're ending up with 12 fitness sco=
res per host genome per generation (or more likely I'm too tired to interpr=
et the paper correctly). 
> 
> I'm my current robot duel implementation I'm=
 simply combining all 24 of these evaluations into a single fitness score p=
assed into the end-of-generation "epoch" method in my NEAT implementation (=
basically a Linux port of Mat Buckland's windows implementation setup as C+=
+ classes). 
> 
> At least in the implementation I currently have, you can =
only have one fitness score per genome in the population.
> 
> Am I correct=
 in combining them, or did you do something else under the hood there with =
multiple fitness scores per genome?
>
